bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, March 2, 1953

div1.p: Hench gives Carbonell advice to pass on to his wife's son about a medical fellowship in the U.S. Hench suggests Carbonell contact Nogueira and request a piece of wood from Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, March 2, 1953
div1.opener:
March 2, 1953
Dr. Felipe Carbonell
San Lazaro 413
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Carbonell:
div1.p:
I have your letter of February 11. First of all, let me say that I did
receive your kind gift to Mrs. Hench, the bottle of perfume, just before
I left and my wife did write to you acknowledging it over a month ago. We
were extremely sorry to hear that you never received her acknowledgement.
There have been several recent dislocations in the mail service. Mrs. Hench just
received a letter which was mailed to her over a month ago. Please accept our
sincere apologies. We are distressed that you did not know that we got it and
hope you will understand that we were not neglectful but most appreciative of
your gift.

I do wish that your wife's son would write to Dr. Victor Johnson, Director
of the Mayo Foundation. I do not want him to get overly enthusiastic or
overly optimistic until he makes the appropriate inquiries and learns exactly
what his chances for fellowship are. The standards for fellowship are ex-
tremely high as I told you and I believe I also wrote to you that very few
young Cuban physicians have been accepted here because so few of them have
met the language requirement. Since all of the patients here are private
patients and most of them of course are Americans, Spanish-speaking physicians
who cannot speak English very well have limited usefulness here. That was
why I suggested that if he did not otherwise qualify without a year in this
country to learn the language, he might do so if he were to spend a year some-
where in this country to learn the language. In view of the fact that ap-
parently your requirements regarding internships in Cuba are not quite the same
as they are here, I do think it would be very important for your wife's son-to
find out as soon as possible just what the requirements are and then if he
wants to try for a fellowship here he can make his plans accordingly. It
might even be advisable for your wife's son to come here for an interview some-
time but that is not necessary yet.

You were very kind to ask Mr. Tarefa to assign me to a window seat when I
left Cuba. Unfortunately the plane left so early in the morning that it was
rather foggy and instead of flying rather close to the harbor as the plane
did on my arrival, the pilot made a wide circle away from Havana so that it
was quite useless and impossible for me to take any pictures. I think we must
have been at least 20 miles east of the harbor at our nearest point, but I
may have better luck next time.

Why don't you call Doctor Nogueira and ask him for a piece of wood from the
caseta? Please see the enclosed letter. Doctor Nogueira is very busy. As
you know, he is carrying on three or four jobs at once. I am sure he would
Dr. Felipe Carbonell
- 2 -
March 2, 1953
make a date to see you and give you the wood. If he doesn't, don't concern
yourself. When I get some from him (I haven't had time to make out my list
yet) I will send you a piece, even if it has to be sent from Cuba here and
then back again.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
